Comment: Please stop conflating the facts.  As I understand the 2 issues.   1. The immunity granted by the Supreme Court extends to the president while doing official duties.  clearly, he could not be prosecuted for something like trying to cut funding to some agency since he would argue he was doing his job, and the courts would probably see it that way.  if he stole $1B in gold from Fort Knox, he would have a tougher time arguing "official duties," though he would certainly try.  if he ordered Seal Team Six to assassinate a political rival, god knows what a court would decide.   2: As for upholding the constitution, that's an entirely different matter  TRUMP took an oath to do that.  however, breaking the oath would not be a crime as far as I know.  The remedy in this case would be impeachment.  in a properly working congress, that is what would happen.  however, it takes a majority of the house of impeach (i.e., accuse) and a majority of the senate to convict, and now that is so political that he would escape unless the balance were to shift in both chambers

Comment: The notion that power is derived from popular consent has always been a convenient fiction for the benefit of those wielding the power. It makes the ruled feel like they have some say in things, when in fact they have very little.  If power is derived from popular consent, then how do the people revoke their consent? And what is supposed to happen if they do? Those are both questions we’ve somehow never had to find the answer to in 250 years because in fact they rule us whether we like it or not. The truth is more along the lines of same Game of Thrones shit. “It’s a trick, a shadow on the wall” etc.
